articles.title: Welcome
articles.description:
I'm an assistant professor at [LEDa, Université Paris-Dauphine](https://leda.dauphine.fr/) in Paris, France. I work on economics relevant to climate change. In particular, I am interested in modeling and estimating climate change impacts, planning and assessing adaptation options, designing mitigation policies, and their specific implications for agriculture.
    
Prior to that, I was Postdoctoral Research Fellow at [the Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI)](https://www.esri.ie/) in Dublin, Ireland. 

I completed my PhD in economics at UMR [Paris-Saclay Applied Economics (PSAE)](https://www6.versailles-grignon.inrae.fr/economie_publique) in September 2021, advised by Stéphane De Cara (INRAE). See [here](https://youtu.be/i2yW7j1fkUk?t=6) for a brief presentation
of my PhD in French.

articles.title: Research
articles.description:
**Research interests:** Environmental economics, agricultural economics, and climate change related issues (impacts, adaptation and mitigation)

**Tools:** Applied modeling, theoretical microeconomics, systematic literature review
articles.contents:
Work in progress
K. de Bruin and L.Henry. An economic assessment of the Paris Agreement for Ireland.
L.Henry. Farmers’ behavioral response toward threshold-based policies.
Working papers
L. Henry. Adapting Geographical Indication to climate change. Conditionally accepted at American Journal of Agricultural Economics. Link to the most recent version
L.Henry. Have economists really “let down the world”? A quantitative overview of the economic literature on climate change. Link to the most recent version
Publication
S. De Cara, L. Henry and P.A. Jayet. 2018. Optimal coverage of an emission tax in the presence of monitoring, reporting, and verification costs. Journal of Environmental Economics and Management. Publisher’s link. Link to preprint.
PhD Thesis
Essays on the economics of climate change: mitigation and adaptation in the agricultural sector
Supervisor: Stéphane De Cara
This thesis addresses economic issues related to climate change, from both a mitigation and an adaptation perspective and with a focus on the implications for agriculture. The three chapters collect different papers in environmental economics, agricultural economics, industrial organization and a systematic literature review.

Brief video presentation in French

systems. Motu Working Paper. Link to working paper

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Micro-econometrics (2022), M1 AID, Université Pars-Dauphine
Teaching assistant for Philippe De Vreyer, in the first year of the Master AID. Bonjour
Advanced econometrics (2021), M1 Master of Economics, Université Paris-Saclay
Teaching assistant for Hugo Molina, Julien Monardo and Margherita Comola in the first year of the Master of Economics. Practical econometric classes on the basic techniques of non-linear econometrics (including nonlinear least squares, maximum likelihood estimator, discrete choice models, sample selection models) and recent developments in the microeconomic analysis of impact evaluation (including randomized controlled experiments, instrumental variables, matching methods, regression discontinuity and difference-in-differences). Link to syllabus.
Econometrics (2017-2021), L3 Economie, ENS Paris-Saclay
Teaching assistant for Jean-Christophe Tavanti in the Social Science Department at ENS Paris-Saclay. Linear econometrics and ordinary least squares estimator (algebraic properties, geometric properties, and inferential properties). Practical classes, to train students practice of econometrics using R and STATA, supervising a short piece of research in data analysis/econometrics. Link to problem sets. Link to syllabus.
